newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian stocks push higher at noon.
newsitem.headline: Australian stocks push higher at noon.

text.p: SPI Futures 2633.0 +9.0 US 30yr cl 6.87 -0.04
10yrbond futs 92.675 +0.020 Gold NY 347.10 Lon fix 343.55
AUD US$0.7612 (local $0.7602) CRB Index cl 248.44 -0.20
*Stocks overcome early dip to record moderate gains to noon
in quiet trade. Volume 168.2 million, A$472.72 million value, 919 stocks
traded, 331 steady, 339 up, 249 down.
Australian stocks pushed higher in late morning trade, consolidating above the 2,600 mark although there was little fresh to drive the market.

The All Ordinaries was up 8.2 points at 2,621.8 after an early dip, with gains spread across the board, but brokers said trade was quiet. "Despite the fact the market is up the activity is not there to go with it," a Sydney-based dealer said.
The June share price index futures contract was up 9.0 points at 2633.0, an 11.2 point premium to the physical market.
The positive tone partially reversed Tuesday's falls, and followed a rise in U.S. blue chips and mixed metals prices.
Brokers said expectations of a further official interest rate cut, which boosted the market on Friday and Monday, appeared to have eased.
Official data showing a 0.9 percent rise in gross domestic product in the March quarter was largely seen as irrelevant. "It all seems a long time ago," one broker noted.
The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ), which went ex-dividend 22 cents, topped morning turnover.
ANZ was down 22 cents at A$8.90, in effect steady, on turnover of 17.6 million shares.
The Commonwealth Bank of Australia was up strongly 45 cents at A$14.14, while the other big banks also made gains.

Bottler Coca-Cola Amatil rose sharply after announcing it had reached final agreement on a share swap deal with San Miguel Corp to acquire the Philippine group's soft drink operations. C-C Amatil briefly breached the A$16.00 level before settling back to A$15.81, a 41-cent gain.

Queensland's Rundle shale oil twins, Central Pacific Minerals and Southern Pacific Petroleum also rose sharply after announcing they had agreed with financiers to proceed with stage one of the long-mooted development of the Stuart shale oil deposit.
In the building sector, James Hardie added another seven cents to A$4.22 ahead of the release of its annual result on Thursday.
Bellwether Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd added 10 cents to A$18.97 and other big miners were also firmer.
Short-term range Support Restnce RSI-14 MA-10 MA-20
*ANZ A$8.89 (-.23) 8.852/8.94 Vol: 17,636,088 ANZ goes ex-dividend, tops turnover.
*Commonwealth A$14.44 14.00/14.45 Vol: 549,343 Commonwealth retraces losses, other big banks firm
*Fosters A$2.63 (-.01) 2.62/2.65 Vol: 1,602,899 Brewer steady as Asahi says considers new relationship
The media sector was off about 1.1 percent, with News Ltd down nine cents to A$5.77.
In other markets, debt futures eased back after the GDP figures were in line with expectations and cast doubts over future policy easings.
Ten year T-bonds were at 92.645, off 0.01 at noon.
The Australian dollar was a touch stronger at US$0.7612 from US$0.7602.
*C-C Amatil A$15.81 (+0.41) 15.40/16.02 Vol: 350,997 Bottler rises on deal with San Miguel of the Philippines
Bellwether rises, other major miners a touch stronger
Rundle twins rise on agreement on shale oil project
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
